24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T1759,<entryFree id="n20811" key="سَمَا" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">سَمَا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M, Msb, K,) first pers. <foreign lang="ar">سَمَوْتُ</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">عَلَوْتُ</foreign>, (S,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَسْمُو</foreign>, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">سُمُوٌّ</foreign>; (S, M, K;) and <foreign lang="ar">سَمِىَ</foreign>, first pers. <foreign lang="ar">سَمِيتُ</foreign>, (Th, S, TA,) like <foreign lang="ar">عَلِيتُ</foreign>; (S;) <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> (a man, Th, S,) or <hi rend="ital">it,</hi> (a thing, M,) <hi rend="ital">was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, high, lofty, raised, upraised, uplifted, upreared, exalted,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">elevated; it rose,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rose high:</hi> (S, M, Msb, K:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20811-1" target="تسامى" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same. (MA. [See also 5.])          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَالِىَ الشَّىْءُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The thing became raised from afar so that I plainly distinguished it:</hi> (K:) or, as in the S, <foreign lang="ar">سَمَا لِىَ الشَّخْصُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the form,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">figure, seen from a distance, rose,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became raised, to me</hi> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">to my view</hi>] <hi rend="ital">so that I plainly distinguished it.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَا الهِلَالُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The moon near the change rose</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مُرْتَفِعًا</foreign> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">upreared, not decumbent:</hi> see <foreign lang="ar">أَدْفَقُ</foreign>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">سَمَا لَهُ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">نَحْوَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He rose, and betook himself, to,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">towards, him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it.</hi> Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">مَاسَمَوْتُ لَكُمْ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I will not</hi> [or (unless the phrase be an apodosis) <hi rend="ital">I did not</hi>] <hi rend="ital">rise and hasten to fight you.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَا بَصَرَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">His sight,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eye, rose,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became raised.</hi> (S, TA.) [And <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاطَرْفُهُ</foreign> lit. signifies the same; but means <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">His look was lofty;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he was proud:</hi> see <foreign lang="ar">سَامٍ</foreign>, below.]          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَا</foreign> is also said of him who is termed <foreign lang="ar">حَسِيبٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">شَرِيفٌ</foreign> [i. e. it signifies <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, noble;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">high,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exalted, in rank</hi>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَتة هِمَّتُهُ إِلَى مَعَالِى الأُمْورِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">His ambition soared,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aspired, to high things,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the means of attaining eminence;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">he sought glory,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">might, and eminence.</hi> (Msb, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَابِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">شَوْقَ بَعْدَ أَنْ كَانَ أَقْصَرَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A yearning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">longing, of the soul arose in me after it had ceased</hi>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">هُمْ يَسْمُونَ عَلَى المِائَةِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They exceed</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">are above</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the number of a hundred.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَوْا</foreign>, (S, K, TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20811-2" target="استموا" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (S,) <hi rend="ital">They went forth to pursue the animals of the chase</hi> (S, K, TA) <hi rend="ital">in their deserts:</hi> (TA:) [or] one says of the hunter, or sportsman, <foreign lang="ar">يَسْمُو الوَحْشَ</foreign>, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20811-3" target="يَسْتَمِيهَا" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">he sees,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">looks to see,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">يَتَعَيَّنُ</foreign>,) <hi rend="ital">the coming forth of the wild animals, and pursues them.</hi> (M. [See also 8 below.])          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَا الفَحْلُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاوَةٌ</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">The stallion sprang,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rushed, upon,</hi> (S,) or <hi rend="ital">he overbore,</hi> (S, * M, K,) <hi rend="ital">his she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth.</hi> (S, M, K.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">سَمَابِهِ</foreign>: see 4.       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  See also 2.    </entryFree>27:Ta51,<entryFree id="n20812" key="سمّاهُ فُلَانًا" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>2</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">سمّاهُ فُلَانًا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth> and        
      <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">بِفُلَانٍ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M, Msb, K,) accord. to Sb originally with <foreign lang="ar">ب</foreign>, but Lh says that the former is that which is usual, (M,) [inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَسْمِيَةٌ</foreign>,] and in like manner   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20812-1" target="اسماهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20814"/></foreign>, (S,) i. e. <foreign lang="ar">اسماهُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانًا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بِفُلَانٍ</foreign>, (M, K,) and accord. to Th, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20812-2" target="سَمَاهُ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فُلَانًا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بِفُلَانٍ</foreign>, (K, [in the correct copies of which the form of the verb first mentioned is without teshdeed, while in the CK the first and last are both alike with teshdeed, or, as is said in the M, Th has mentioned <foreign lang="ar">سَمَوْتُهُ</foreign>, but none other has mentioned it,]) <hi rend="ital">He named him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">called him, Such a one;</hi> (S, M, Msb, K;) as Zeyd; i. e., he made Zeyd to be his name, his proper name. (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [One says also, <foreign lang="ar">سمّى ٱللّٰهَ عَلَى شَىْءٍ</foreign>, or simply <foreign lang="ar">سمّى عَلَيْهِ</foreign>, which is the more common, meaning <hi rend="ital">He pronounced the name of God, saying</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِسْمِ ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> (<hi rend="ital">In the name of God</hi>), <hi rend="ital">upon,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">over, a thing;</hi> such as food, and an animal about to be slaughtered.] The Prophet said, <foreign lang="ar">سَمُّوا وَسَمِّتُوا وَدَنُّوا</foreign>, [cited, with some variations, and expl., in arts. <foreign lang="ar">دنو</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">سمت</foreign>,] meaning <foreign lang="ar">سَمُّوا ٱللّٰهَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Pronounce ye the name of God,</hi> &amp;c.]; i. e. whenever ye eat, [before ye begin to do so, accord. to the general custom, or] between two mouthfuls. (M.)    </entryFree>28:Te1a,<entryFree id="n20813" key="ساماهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>3</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ساماهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M, K, TA,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">مُسَامَاةٌ</foreign>, (TA,) <hi rend="ital">He vied, competed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contended for superiority, in highness, loftiness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">eminence,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in glory,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excellence,</hi> [or in an absolute sense,] <hi rend="ital">with him;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">عَالَاهُ</foreign>, (M,) or <foreign lang="ar">فَاخَرَهُ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">بَارَاهُ</foreign>. (K.) It is said in the trad. respecting the lie [against 'Áïsheh], <foreign lang="ar">لَمْ تَكُنِ ٱمْرَأَةٌ تُسَامِيهَا غَيْرُ زَيْنَبَ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">There was not any woman that vied with her in eminence</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">تُفَاخِرُهَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تُعَالِيهَا</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">except Zeyneb;</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">المُسَامَاةُ</foreign> meaning <foreign lang="ar">المُطَاوَلَةُ فِى الحُِظْوَةِ</foreign>. (TA.) And one says, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ لَا يُسَامَى وَقَدْ عَلَا مَنْ سَامَاهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Such a one will not be vied with in highness,</hi> &amp;c.: <hi rend="ital">and he has overcome him who vied with him,</hi> &amp;c.]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ أَمَامِى مَا لَا أُسَامِى</foreign>, said when one fears an affair, or event, before him; on the authority <pb n="1434"/> of IAar; meaning [<hi rend="ital">Verily before me is an affair,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">event,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">with which I cannot vie.</hi> (M.) A poet cited by Th says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">بَاتَ ٱبْنُ أَدْمَآءَ يُسَامِى الأَنْدَرَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">سَامَى طَعَامَ الحَىِّ حَتَّى نَوَّرَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> and he says that <foreign lang="ar">سَامَى</foreign> means <foreign lang="ar">اِرْتَفَعَ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">صَعِدَ</foreign>; but [it seems that the verse should be rendered, <hi rend="ital">Ibn-Admà passed the night aspiring to reach the heap of reaped wheat: he aspired to attain the wheat of the tribe until it attained to maturity:</hi> for ISd says,] in my opinion he means, as the seed-produce rose by growth, he rose to it, until it attained to maturity, when he reaped it and stole it: and he cites also the saying, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">فَٱرْفَعْ يَدَيْكَ ثُمَّ سَامِ الحَنْجَرَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">And raise thy hands, then endeavour to reach the windpipe</hi>]; explaining <foreign lang="ar">سَامِ الحَنْجَرَ</foreign> as meaning <hi rend="ital">raise thy hands to his</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">حَلْق</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">throat,</hi> properly, <hi rend="ital">fauces</hi>]. (M.)    </entryFree>29:T94b,<entryFree id="n20814" key="اسماهُ" type="main">

                  <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (a hunter, or sportsman, [<foreign lang="ar">الصّاعِدُ</foreign> in the CK being a mistranscription for <foreign lang="ar">الصَّائِدُ</foreign>,]) <hi rend="ital">attired himself with the socks,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stockings, called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِسْمَاة</foreign>, (M, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">to protect himself from the heat of the burning ground,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">for the hunting of gazelles, in the time of heat.</hi> (M.) And (M, in the K “ or ”) <foreign lang="ar">استماهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He asked of him the loan of the socks,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stockings, above named, for that purpose,</hi> (M, K, *) i. e. <hi rend="ital">for the hunting of gazelles at midday.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">استمى</foreign>, (M, CK,) or <foreign lang="ar">استمى الظِّبَآءَ</foreign>, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) <hi rend="ital">He sought,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pursued, the gazelles in their caves,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hiding-places,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">فَى غِيرَانِهَا</foreign>, M, and so in copies of the K, by the <foreign lang="ar">غِيرَان</foreign> being meant the <foreign lang="ar">كُنُس</foreign>, M,) or <hi rend="ital">in what was not their time,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">season,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">فِى غَيْرِ ٱنِهَا</foreign>, thus in some copies of the K,) <hi rend="ital">at the auroral rising of Canopus</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">سُهَيْل</foreign> [which rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.]): (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.) [Freytag says, on the authority of scholia to the Deewán of Jereer, as follows: In the time of the greatest heat, they drive out a wild animal repeatedly from its hiding-place, permitting it to return thither at night, when, thus disturbed, it does not issue from its place; in order that they may be able to strike it.]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">He hunted,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chased, wild animals.</hi> (M.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  See also 1, latter part, in two places.          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And see 4.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">اِسْتَمَيْتُهُ</foreign> also signifies <hi rend="ital">I made him the object of a visit:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">I perceived in him good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goodness, by a right opinion formed from its outward signs.</hi> (K.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">استماهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He chose it, took it in preference,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">selected it.</hi> (IAar, L voce <foreign lang="ar">اِقْتَرَحَ</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And IAar mentions the saying, <foreign lang="ar">البَكْرَةُ مِنَ الإِبِلِ تُسْتَمَى بَعْدَ أَرْبَعَ عَشْرَةَ لَيْلَةً أَوْبَعْدَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">إِحْدَى وَعِشْرِينَ</foreign>, as meaning [<hi rend="ital">The youthful she-camel</hi>] <hi rend="ital">is tested for the purpose of discovering whether or not she be pregnant</hi> [<hi rend="ital">after fourteen nights or after one and twenty</hi>]: but Th disallows this, and says that the word is <foreign lang="ar">تُسْتَمْنَى</foreign>, from <foreign lang="ar">المُنْيَةُ</foreign>, which means “ the period by the end of which one knows whether or not the she-camel is pregnant. ” (M.)    </entryFree>2d:T220a,<entryFree id="n20821" key="سَمَآءٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> The <hi rend="ital">higher,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upper,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">highest,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">uppermost, part</hi> of anything: [in this sense] masc. (M.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [In its predominant acceptation,] a word of well-known meaning; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) [The <hi rend="ital">sky,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">heaven;</hi>] the <hi rend="ital">canopy of the earth:</hi> (M, Msb, TA:) in this sense (M, Msb) masc. and fem.; (IAmb, S, M, Msb, K; *) sometimes fem.; (M;) rarely so, and thus as having the next but one of the significations here following: (Fr, Msb:) Az says that it is fem. because it is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءَةٌ</foreign>: (TA:) or it is as though it were pl. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-1" target="سَمَاوَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20827"/></foreign>, [or rather its coll. gen. n.,] like as <foreign lang="ar">سَحَابٌ</foreign> is of <foreign lang="ar">سَحَابَةٌ</foreign>: (Msb, TA:) Er-Rághib says that the <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآء</foreign> as opposed to the <foreign lang="ar">أَرْض</foreign> is fem., and sometimes masc.; and is used as a sing. and as a pl.; as the latter in the Kur ii. 27 [where it is shown to apply to seven heavens]; and that it is like <foreign lang="ar">نَخْلٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">شَجَرٌ</foreign> and other [coll.] gen. ns.: (TA:) in this sense (M) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمِيَةٌ</foreign> [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">سُمِىٌّ</foreign>, (M, K,) the latter [originally <foreign lang="ar">سُمُوىٌ</foreign>] of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فُعُولٌ</foreign>, and both [also] pls. of <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</foreign> in another sense, mentioned in what follows, (TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاوَاتٌ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">سَمٰوَاتٌ</foreign>, (S, M, Msb, K,) and accord. to the K, [in which all of these are mentioned as though pls. of <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</foreign> in all its senses,]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-2" target="سَمًا" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20819"/></foreign>, [in the CK <foreign lang="ar">سُمًا</foreign>,] but in the M <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</foreign> [like the sing., as mentioned above], where it is said that it must be a pl. in the Kur ii. 27 for the reason already stated, as though pl. of <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءَةٌ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاوَةٌ</foreign>; (TA;) and a poet assigns to <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</foreign> the anomalous pl. <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٍ</foreign>, by his saying, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءُ ٱلْإِلٰهِ فَوْقَ سَبْعِ سَمَآئِيَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">The heaven of God, above seven heavens</hi>]: (S, M:) the dim. is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-3" target="سُمّيَّةٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (Ham p. 452.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">Any canopy,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">covering over-head, of a person.</hi> (S, Msb, * TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  And hence, (S, TA,) The <hi rend="ital">ceiling,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">roof,</hi> (S, Msb, K, TA,) of a house, or chamber, or tent, (S, K, TA,) and of anything; (K, TA;) in this sense masc.; (Msb, TA;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-4" target="سَمَاوَةٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20827"/></foreign> also has this meaning.                   <foreign lang="ar">شُقَّةٌ</foreign>, (M,) of a <foreign lang="ar">بَيْت</foreign> [or tent]; (M, K;) in which sense it is fem., and sometimes masc.; (M;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-5" target="سَمَاوَةٌ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20827"/></foreign>; (M, K;) [and so, app.,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20821-6" target="سِمَايَةٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20828"/></foreign>; for] one says, <foreign lang="ar">أَصْلَحَ سِمَايَتَهُ</foreign>, with kesr, [<hi rend="ital">He repaired his</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">سماية</foreign>,] meaning, his <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاوَة</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">clouds;</hi> (Zj, K;) because of their height: (Zj, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a cloud.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And <hi rend="ital">Rain;</hi> (S, M, Msb, K;) because it comes forth from the <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآء</foreign> [i. e. sky or clouds]: (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a good rain</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَطْرَةٌ جَيِّدَةٌ</foreign>): (K, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">a new rain</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَطْرَةٌ جَدِيدَةٌ</foreign>): (T, TA:) or, as some say, <hi rend="ital">rain that has not fallen upon the earth;</hi> so called in consideration of what has been said above [of its meaning the “ clouds ” &amp;c.]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [but] one says, <foreign lang="ar">مَا زِلْنَا نَطَأُ السَّمَآءَ حَتَّى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَتَيْنَاكُمْ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">We ceased not to tread upon the rain until we came to you</hi>]: (S, TA:) applied to rain, it is masc., and fem. also because of its connexion with the <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآء</foreign> that canopies the earth; (M;) or it is fem., as meaning <foreign lang="ar">سَحَابَةٌ</foreign>: (Msb:) the pl. [of mult.] is <foreign lang="ar">سُمِىٌّ</foreign> (S, M, Msb, TA) and [of pauc.] <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمِيَةٌ</foreign>. (S, TA.) <foreign lang="ar">بَنُو مَآءِ السَّمَآءِ</foreign> is an appellation of <hi rend="ital">The Arabs;</hi> [signifying <hi rend="ital">the sons of the water of the heaven;</hi>] because of their keeping much to the deserts which are the places of the falling of rain [by means of which they subsist]: or by <foreign lang="ar">مَآء السمآء</foreign> is meant <hi rend="ital">Zemzem,</hi> which God made to well forth for the Arabs, who are therefore like the sons thereof. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  [Hence, app., as <pb n="1435"/> being likened to rain by reason of the swiftness of his running,] a certain horse, (M, K,) belonging to Sakhr the brother of El-Khansà, (M,) was named <foreign lang="ar">السَّمَآءُ</foreign>. (M, K.)          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  [Hence, likewise, as being likened to rain, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Bounty.</hi>] One says, <foreign lang="ar">أَصَابَنِى بِرَشْحَةٍ مِنْ سَمَائِهِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He gave me a gift from his store of bounty</hi>]. (A in art. <foreign lang="ar">رشح</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  Also <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Herbage;</hi> because produced by the rain, which is thus called. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">back</hi> of a horse; (S, Msb, K;) because of its height: coupled with [its opposite] <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign> [q. v.]. (S, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="12">-b12-</sense>  And of a sandal, [in like manner opposed to <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign>,] The <hi rend="ital">upper part</hi> [<hi rend="ital">of the sole,</hi> i. e. the <hi rend="ital">upper surface thereof</hi>], <hi rend="ital">upon which the foot is placed.</hi> (M.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">سَمَاوَةٌ</foreign>.    </entryFree>2e:T55f,<entryFree id="n20827" key="سَمَاوَةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">سَمَاوَةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>: see <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآءٌ</foreign>, in three places.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also The <hi rend="ital">form,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">figure, seen from a distance,</hi> (S, M, K, TA,) [or] <hi rend="ital">such as is high,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">elevated,</hi> (TA,) of anything; (S, M, K, TA;) and the <hi rend="ital">aspect</hi> thereof: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20827-1" target="سَمَآءٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20821"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20827-2" target="سَمَاوٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20822"/></foreign>; the latter mentioned by Ks. (M, TA.) El-'Ajjáj says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">سَمَآوَةُ الهِلَالِ حَتَّى ٱحْقَوْقَفَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">The form,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">of the moon when near the change, until it became curved</hi>]. (S.)    </entryFree>2f:Tba8,<entryFree id="n20830" key="سَامٍ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">سَامٍ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">High,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lofty;</hi> as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20830-1" target="سَمِىٌّ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20823"/></foreign>: pl. of the former <foreign lang="ar">سَوَامٍ</foreign>; applied to women as pl. of <foreign lang="ar">سَامِيَةٌ</foreign>, whence the phrase <foreign lang="ar">سَوَامِى الطَّرْفِ</foreign> in a verse cited voce <foreign lang="ar">بُضْعٌ</foreign>; and to irrational animals, as in an instance here following]. One says <foreign lang="ar">القُرُومُ السَّوَامِى</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The stallions</hi> [meaning <hi rend="ital">the stallion-camels high in their heads,</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">raising their heads high.</hi> (S, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">سَامِيَاتٌ</foreign>, [pl. of <foreign lang="ar">سَامِيَةٌ</foreign>,] applied to camels, <hi rend="ital">That raise,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">raise high, their eyes and their heads.</hi> (Ham p. 791.) And <foreign lang="ar">رَدَدْتُ مِنْ سَامِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">طَرْفِهِ</foreign> [app. an elliptical phrase, <foreign lang="ar">نَخْوَتَهُ</foreign> (which is expressed in the explanation) or a similar word being understood; i. e. <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I repelled the pride,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">haughtiness, of him who was lofty in look;</hi>] meaning <hi rend="ital">I contracted to him</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">to the lofty in look</hi>] <hi rend="ital">his soul, and annulled his pride,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">haughtiness.</hi> (S, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20830-2" target="سَمِىُّ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الأَنْفِ</foreign> [lit. <hi rend="ital">Highnosed</hi>] means <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">disdainful,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scornful.</hi> (T and K in art. <foreign lang="ar">انف</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Also act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses.          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And hence,] <foreign lang="ar">سُمَاةٌ</foreign>, (S, M, K,) of which it is the sing., (M,) signifies <hi rend="ital">Hunters</hi> (S, M, K) <hi rend="ital">going forth to the chase:</hi> (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: or, as some say, <hi rend="ital">hunters in the day-time,</hi> peculiarly: or <hi rend="ital">hunters wearing the socks,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stockings, called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِسْمَاة</foreign>. (M.)    </entryFree>30:T2257,<entryFree id="n20831" key="اِسْمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اِسْمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أسام</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أسم</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أسمى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">اسم</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">سام</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">سم</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">سما</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">سمى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">وسم</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ٱسم</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M, Msb, K,) with the conjunctive <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign>, [i. e. written <foreign lang="ar">ٱسْمٌ</foreign>,] but this is made disjunctive by poetic license [as well as when the word commences a sentence], (S,) usually with kesr [when the | is disjunctive], (Lh, M, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">اُسْمٌ</foreign>, (S, M, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-'Amr-Ibn-Temeem and of Kudá'ah, (M, TA,) mentioned by IAar, (TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-1" target="سِمٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20818"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-2" target="سُمٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> (S, M, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-3" target="سَمٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-4" target="سُمًا" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20820"/></foreign> (M, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-5" target="سِمًا" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-6" target="سَمًا" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20819"/></foreign>, (K,) [The <hi rend="ital">name</hi> of a thing; i. e.] <hi rend="ital">a sign</hi> [<hi rend="ital">such as may be uttered or written</hi>] <hi rend="ital">conveying knowledge</hi> of a thing; syn. <foreign lang="ar">عَلَامَةٌ</foreign>: and <hi rend="ital">a word applied to denote a substance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an accident</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attribute, for the purpose of distinction:</hi> (M, K:) [or <hi rend="ital">a substantive in the proper sense of this term,</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">a real substantive;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a substance in a tropical sense of this term,</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">an ideal substantive:</hi>] as expl. by El-Munáwee, in the “ Towkeef, ” the <foreign lang="ar">اسم</foreign> is <hi rend="ital">that which denotes a meaning in itself unconnected with any of the three times</hi> [<hi rend="ital">past and present and future</hi>]: <hi rend="ital">if denoting what subsists by itself, it is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمُ عَيْنٍ</foreign>; and <hi rend="ital">if denoting what does not subsist by itself,</hi> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">an accident</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attribute,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">whether existent, as</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">العِلْمُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">knowledge</hi>], <hi rend="ital">or non-existent, as</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الجَهْلُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">ignorance</hi>], <hi rend="ital">it is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمُ مَعْنًى</foreign>: (TA:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَآءٌ</foreign> [a pl. of pauc.] and <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَاوَاتٌ</foreign>, (S, M, K,) the latter said by Lh to be a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمٌ</foreign>, but it is rather a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَآءٌ</foreign>, for otherwise there is no way of accounting for it, (M,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَسَامٍ</foreign> (S, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">أَسَامِىُّ</foreign> (M, K) are [likewise] pls. of <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَآءٌ</foreign>: (K, * TA:) the word <foreign lang="ar">ٱسْمٌ</foreign> [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمٌ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">اُسْمٌ</foreign>] is derived from <foreign lang="ar">سَمَوْتُ</foreign>, (S, TA,) or from <foreign lang="ar">السُّمُوُّ</foreign>, (Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) because the <foreign lang="ar">اسم</foreign> is a means of raising into notice the thing denoted thereby, and making it known: (S, * Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the measure <foreign lang="ar">اِفْعٌ</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">اُفْعٌ</foreign>, accord. to different dialects], the last radical, <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign>, being wanting in it, (S, Msb, TA,) and the hemzeh [or rather |] being prefixed by way of compensation for it, accord to a general rule; (Msb, TA;) for it is originally <foreign lang="ar">سِمْوٌ</foreign> (S, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA) or <foreign lang="ar">سُمْوٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb, TA,) its pl. being <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَآءٌ</foreign>, and its dim. being   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-7" target="سُمَىٌّ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20824"/></foreign> [originally <foreign lang="ar">سَمَيْوٌ</foreign>]: (S, Msb, Er-Rághib, * TA:) some of the Koofees hold that it is from <foreign lang="ar">الوَسْمُ</foreign>, meaning <foreign lang="ar">العَلَامَةُ</foreign>, the <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign>, which is the primal radical, being rejected, and the hemzeh [or |] being substituted for it, so that its measure is <foreign lang="ar">اِعْلٌ</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">اُعْلٌ</foreign>]; but this is a weak opinion, for, were it so, the dim. would be <foreign lang="ar">وَسَيْمٌ</foreign> and the pl. would be <foreign lang="ar">أَوْسَامٌ</foreign>. (Msb, TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمُ هٰذَا كَذَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The name of this is thus,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">such a word</hi>]; and if you will you may say, <foreign lang="ar">اُسْمُ هٰذا كذا</foreign>; and in like manner,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-8" target="سِمُهُ" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-9" target="سُمُهُ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: Lh says that <foreign lang="ar">اِسْمُهُ فُلَانٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">His name is Such a one</hi>] is the [common] phrase of the Arabs; and he mentions <foreign lang="ar">اُسْمُهُ فُلَانٌ</foreign> as heard from [the tribe of] Benoo-'Amr-Ibn-Temeem: and Ks cites, as heard from some of [the tribe of] Benoo-Kudá'ah, the saying, <quote>
                     <L>  
      <foreign lang="ar">بِٱسْمِ ٱلَّذِى فِى كُلِّ سُورَةٍ <ref cref="n20831-10" target="سُمُهْ" n="10" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar"/></foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">In the name of Him whose name is in every chapter of the Kur-án</hi>], and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-11" target="سِمُهْ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> as heard from others, not of Kudá'ah. (M.) <foreign lang="ar">سِرْ عَلَى ٱسْمِ ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> is an elliptical phrase [for <foreign lang="ar">سِرْ مُعْتَمِدًا عَلَى ذِكْرِ ٱسْمِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ٱللّٰهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Journey thou relying upon the mention of the name of God</hi>]. (IJ, M in art. <foreign lang="ar">دل</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">دَلِيلٌ</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">ٱسْمٌ</foreign> signifies also <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Fame, renown, report,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reputation,</hi> of a person: (TA:) and so   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n20831-12" target="سُمًا" n="12" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n20820"/></foreign>, <hi rend="ital">in relation to good,</hi> (K, TA,) not to evil; mentioned by Az. (TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">ذَهَبَ ٱسْمُهُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِى النَّاسِ</foreign>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">His fame</hi> &amp;c. [<hi rend="ital">went,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">spread, among mankind,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the people</hi>].
